f: Former regent Dong Xian, who was previously Ai's lover, commits suicide with his wife.
August – Emperor Ai dies and is succeeded by his young cousin Ping, who is enthroned on October. Wang Mang is appointed regent by Empress Dowager Wang Zhengjun, his aunt.
Kunatala Satakarni is succeeded by Satakarni III.

Estimated birth of Jesus, in the Christian religion, as assigned by Dionysius Exiguus in his Anno Domini era; according to most scholars, Dionysius used the word "incarnation", but it is not known whether he meant conception or birth. However, at least one scholar thinks Dionysius placed the incarnation of Jesus in the next year,.
Aulus Caecina Severus was appointed consul by Emperor Augustus, succeeding Cossus Cornelius Lentulus Gaetulicus and Lucius Calpurnius Piso.
Dedication of the Forum Augustum.
Tigranes IV and Erato are restored to the throne after deposing Artavasdes III.
Date of the birth of Jesus according to the writings of Tertullian, Eusebius and Epiphanius (probably after the statement of Jesus being "around some years old" in ).

February – Augustus is proclaimed pater patriae ("father of the country") by the Roman Senate. This bestowed title is the logical consequence and final proof of Augustus' supreme position as princeps, the first in charge over the Roman state.
Julia the Elder, daughter of Augustus, is exiled on charges of treason and adultery to Pandateria; her mother Scribonia accompanies her.
Augustus' second census of the Roman Empire reports a total of,233, citizens. However, the specific criteria of the census are still not clear.
May – Emperor Ai succeeds to the throne of Han China.
Rome is divided in administrative regions.
Sextilis, the eighth month of the early Julian calendar, is renamed Augustus by a decree of the Roman Senate in honor of Augustus.
Arminius, son of a Cheruscan chieftain, is taken as a hostage to Rome, where he receives a military education.
King Maroboduus becomes ruler of the Marcomanni and fights against the Roman Empire's expansion in Bohemia.
After some years, Emperor Augustus initiates his second census of the Roman Empire.
Accession of Aretas IV Philopatris as King of the Nabataeans (modern Jordan).
Pannonia is incorporated into the Roman Empire as part of Illyria.
Livy completes compilation of his Ab Urbe Condita Libri, 142 books covering the history of Rome since its foundation down to (approximate date).
January – The Ara Pacis ("Altar of Augustan Peace"), voted for by the Senate four years earlier, is dedicated.
Nero Claudius Drusus, Emperor Augustus' stepson, begins a campaign against the Marcomanni, but dies soon after, due to a fall from his horse.

The usurper Wang Mang (who rules during a brief interregnum known as the Xin dynasty) outlaws the private purchase and use of crossbows. Despite this, Liu Xiu, the later Emperor Guangwu of Han, buys crossbows in the winter of to aid the rebellion of his brother Liu Yan (styled Bosheng) and Li Tong.
Differentiation of localized Teutonic tribes of the Irminones.
Ovid completes Tristia III (the "Sorrows") describing the sadness of banishment.
According to the Gospel of Luke, Jesus visits Herod's Temple and gets lost.
The Euthydemid dynasty, a Greek dynasty in Bactria, is brought to an end.
The Obelisk of Montecitorio is brought from Egypt to Rome by Emperor Augustus to be erected as a sundial gnomon of the Solarium Augusti. It is now in the Piazza Montecitorio.
The Romans build a bridge across the Rhine near Bonn (approximate date).
A Roman military camp is established at Speyer.
Artabanus II becomes ruler of Parthia.
The yellow river experiences a major flood. This flood is credited for the downfall of the short-lived Xin dynasty.
Germania Inferior and the Rhine are secured by Germanicus.

An edict is issued effecting an empire-wide ban on divinatory practices, especially astrology. The edict requires any consultation between a customer and a practitioner to be conducted with at least one third party witness present, and bans inquiry into anyone's death.
Emperor Augustus abandons his plan to create a defensive border at the Elbe, in order to reinforce the Roman defenses along the Rhine and the Danube.
May – Drusus secures the Rhine frontier and builds Roman fortresses near Bonn, Dorsten, Haltern, and Oberaden.
Battle of the Lupia River: Roman forces under Augustus's stepson Nero Claudius Drusus win a victory in Germania.
Battle of Arbalo: Roman forces under Augustus's stepson Nero Claudius Drusus beat off a German ambush.
Quintus Aelius Tubero and Paullus Fabius Maximus are Roman Consuls.
Quirinius returns from Judea to become a counselor to Tiberius.
Ovid stops writing Fasti, because of the lack of resources (being far from the libraries of Rome). He completes books that detail festivals found in the Roman calendar.
Augustus orders a major invasion of Germany beyond the Rhine.
Annius Rufus is appointed Prefect of Judea.
The Armenian Artaxiad dynasty is overthrown by the Romans.

Halley's Comet makes an appearance, as recorded by Chinese Astronomers for about days. Written in the Annal of Han as "In the first year of Yuan Yen ( B.C.), in the Autumn the seventh month, on the day Sing Wei, a comet swept in Gemini, went through Pollux and Castor, and passed over Leo and Virgo.
Tiberius Claudius Nero summoned to Pannonia due to severe revolt by the Delmatae.
Roman armies based at Xanten, Cologne and Mainz campaign beyond the Rhine.
First official mention of Argentoratum, the city known in modern times as Strasbourg.
Emperor Augustus is given the title Pontifex Maximus.
Emperor Augustus initiates his third census of the Roman Empire after some years.
Strabo publishes his book on the shape of the Earth.
Ovid publishes books - of his Epistulae ex Ponto.
The Senate passes a senatus consultum restricting the reduced Vigintisexviri to the Ordo Equester.
Abgarus of Edessa is reinstalled as king of Osroene.
The Ara Pacis Augustae ("Altar of Augustan Peace") is commissioned by the Roman Senate to honor the triumphal return of Emperor Augustus from Hispania and Gaul.
The Roman general Nero Claudius Drusus builds the stronghold of castrum Moguntiacum in the location of the modern-day city of Mainz, Germany.
Revolt in Thrace against Roman rule led by Vologases.
Tiberius Claudius Nero and Publius Quinctilius Varus are Roman Consuls.
Drusus is granted governor of Gaul and mobilises a Roman army to beat the Germans back across the Rhine. He travels to the North Sea and pays tribute to the Frisii.
September – Tiberius succeeds his stepfather Augustus as Roman emperor.
The town and port of Nauportus are plundered by a mutinous Roman legion that was sent there to build roads and bridges.
Germanicus is appointed commander of the forces in Germany, beginning a campaign that will end in.
Augustus' third (and final) -year census of the Roman Empire reports a total of,973, citizens.
Sextus Appuleius and Sextus Pompeius serve as Roman consuls.
Winter – The Roman Legio X Fretensis is stationed in Syria, and the legionaries are settled at the ancient city of Beirut.
Caesar Augustus makes Beeroth (modern Beirut) a colonia, named Colonia Julia Augusta Felix Berytus.
The Roman general Nero Claudius Drusus fortifies Augusta Vangionum, the modern city of Worms, Germany.
Summer – Germanicus launches a two-pronged attack from Vetera and Moguntiacum. On his return journey, he recaptures the aquila of Legio XIX and visits the battlefield of the Teutoburg Forest.
May – As part of his campaign against the Germanic peoples, Germanicus captures Thusnelda, wife of Arminius.
Varna, on the Bulgarian Black Sea Coast, is annexed to the Roman province of Moesia.
Early (approx.) – Emona (on the site of modern-day Ljubljana) is founded by Legio XV Apollinaris.
The river Tiber floods parts of Rome.

The Raeti tribes of the Alps are subjugated by Tiberius and Nero Claudius Drusus and the new Roman province of Raetia is established with Chur (in modern-day Switzerland) as its capital. During the campaign, Roman triremes destroy the fleet of the Vindelici in the Battle of Lake Constance.
Drusus decides to improve the passage through the Alps for military control of Noricum and Raetia and builds the Via Claudia Augusta through Italy.
Marcus Livius Drusus Libo and Lucius Calpurnius Piso are Roman Consuls.

Germanicus employs the North Sea fleet to avoid dangerous rivers, embarking an army in the Rhine Delta, aboard circa, ships. He defeats the Germans at the Amisius river estuary and the Weser, but during its return, the Roman fleet is partially destroyed by storms.
A Roman army of, men commanded by Germanicus gains a great victory at Idistaviso, defeating the German war chief Arminius, and recovering the lost eagles of Varus' legions.
Ovid's "Epistulae ex Ponto" appears.
Vonones, the beleaguered king of Armenia, is summoned to Syria, by Roman governor Creticus Silanus.
Construction of the Roman temple of Maison Carrée at Nîmes in Gallia Narbonensis (approximate date).
The Noricans having joined with the Pannonians in invading Histria, are defeated by Publius Silius Nerva, proconsul of Illyricum.
Noricum is incorporated into the Roman Empire.
Caesar Augustus reorganizes the German provinces, making Trier their capital.
Clades Lolliana: Roman consul Marcus Lollius is defeated by a Germanic horde.
May – Germanicus returns to Rome as a conquering hero; he celebrates a triumph for his victories over the Cherusci, Chatti and other Germanic tribes west of the Elbe.
Cappadocia (Asia Minor) becomes a Roman province.

Tacfarinas, Numidian deserter from the Roman army, begins a guerrilla war against the Romans. He leads his own Musulamii tribe and a coalition of Berbers, attacking the Limes Tripolitanus, a fortified zone of the Roman Empire in Africa.
Emperor Tiberius sends Germanicus to the east, in order to lead a military campaign against Parthia.
Herod Antipas, son of Herod the Great, builds the city Tiberias on the western shore of the Sea of Galilee, in honor of Tiberius.
A vexillatio (sub-unit or detachment) of Legio III Augusta is destroyed by an ambush in Africa.
Daemusin becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
Winter – Germanicus Caesar arrives in Syria, as new commander-in-chief for the Roman East.
After a flooding of the Yellow River in China, farmers are forced to rebel. Emperor Wang Mang reacts by sending an army (some, men) against the agrarian rebels.
Germanicus concludes a peace treaty with Artabanus II of Parthia, in which he is recognized as king and friend of Rome.

Caesar Augustus introduces the Lex Julia (Julian Laws): Lex Iulia de Ambitu penalised bribery when acquiring political offices. Lex Iulia de maritandis ordinibus introduced penalties and incentives to promote marriage, and forbade marriage of senators, as well as of their children, to prostitutes and to freedmen.
Lex Iulia de maritandis ordinibus introduced penalties and incentives to promote marriage, and forbade marriage of senators, as well as of their children, to prostitutes and to freedmen.
Lex Iulia de Ambitu penalised bribery when acquiring political offices.
Onjo becomes the first ruler of the Korean kingdom of Baekje (traditional date).
First flying machine, according to the Hanshu.

Germanicus Julius Caesar, commander in chief of the Roman legions in the East and beloved by the legionaries, falls ill and dies. On his deathbed he accuses Gnaeus Calpurnius Piso, the governor of Syria, of poisoning him.
A triumphal arch is built for Germanicus Julius Caesar in Saintes.
Gondophares becomes king of the Saces.
Emperor Tiberius expels the Egyptians from Rome, and deports, Jews from Sicily.
Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa completes the Aqua Virgo; the aqueduct is km in length and supplies the city of Rome with about,, liters of water every day.
King Yuri becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
The Aeneid by the Roman poet Virgil is published after his death. The Aeneid is an epic poem in books that tells the story of the foundation of Rome from the ashes of Troy.
In Rome, Lucius Cornelius Balbus receives the honor of a triumph on the Forum Romanum, for his victories over the Garamantes in Africa.
The Cantabrians, living on the northernmost coast of Spain, are brought under Roman control. The region is completely subdued until.
Maison Carrée, Nîmes, France, is built (approximate date).
The Shakas, a nomadic Iranian tribe, no longer control northwest India (approximate date).
Based on the scenes and the style of the work, the Portland Vase is believed to have been made in Alexandria some time between this year and.
Marcus Verrius Flaccus' De verborum significatu is published. It is one of the first great dictionaries in history.
King Herod the Great begins renovation of the Temple in Jerusalem.
The manufacture of pens and metal writing tools begins in Rome (approximate date).
King Daeso of Dongbuyeo is killed in battle against the armies of Goguryeo, led by its third ruler, King Daemusin.
Barracks are constructed for the Praetorian Guard, on the Quirinal (located on the Seven Hills of Rome).
Emperor Tiberius is a Roman Consul for the fourth time.
The Aedui revolt under Julius Florus and Julius Sacrovir; the revolt is suppressed by Gaius Silius.
Aemilius Lepidus Paullus and Lucius Munatius Plancus are Censors.
King Artaxias II returns, with the support of the Parthians, to Armenia and claims the throne. Artavasdes I escapes to Rome, where Caesar Augustus receives him.
The Roman governor of Egypt, Gaius Petronius, marches up the Nile with legions XXII Deiotariana and III Cyrenaica, and destroys the Nubian capital of Napata.
Emperor Tiberius' son Drusus Julius Caesar dies. From that point forward, Tiberius seems to lose interest in the Empire and occupies himself with the pursuit of pleasure.
Greek geographer Strabo publishes Geographica, a work covering the world known to the Romans and Greeks at the time of Emperor Augustus – it is the only such book to survive from the ancient world.
Liu Xuan, a descendant of the Han dynasty royal family and leader of insurgents against the Xin dynasty, proclaims himself emperor against Wang Mang.
October – Emperor Liu Xuan's forces kill Wang Mang at the end of a three-day siege.

July – After being under siege for two months, about, insurgents under Liu Xiu defeat 450, of Wang Mang's troops in the Battle of Kunyang, ushering in the fall of Wang Mang's Xin dynasty and restoration of the Han dynasty.

The Roman writer, architect and engineer Marcus Vitruvius Pollio finishes writing De Architectura (known today as The Ten Books of Architecture), a treatise in Latin on architecture, and perhaps the first work about this discipline.
Caesar Augustus becomes Roman consul for the eleventh time. His co-consul is Aulus Terentius Varro Murena.
In response to Meroë's incursions into Upper Egypt, the Roman legions move south and raze Napata. (History of Sudan).
The earliest documented instance of wrestling in Japan.
Augustus relinquishes the position of consul, retains that of tribune of Rome, and assumes that of Princeps, or "First Citizen." (see Roman Empire).
The Masinissa line of the rulers of Carthage ends.
July – Midway through the Roman year 777 A.U.C., Gaius Calpurnius Aviola and Publius Lentulus Scipio begin the new consular year as the new suffect consuls.
The Senate expels actors from Rome.The factual accuracy of part of this article is disputed. The dispute is about At least if quoted correctly here Tacitus. says this event took place in..

June – The terms of Servius Cornelius Cethegus and Lucius Visellius Varro as Roman consuls expire. During their terms, two laws pertaining to slavery had been passed, the lex Visellia de iure Quiritium Latinorum qui inter vigiles militaverant granting freed slaves Roman citizenship after six years service, and the Lex Visellia de poenis libertinorum qui ingenuorum honores usurpabant which penalized non-citizens who falsely claimed to be ingenui or freeborn Romans.
The revolt of Tacfarinas revolt in Africa is repressed.
Caesar Augustus becomes Roman Consul for the tenth time. His partner is Gaius Norbanus Flaccus.
Herod the Great marries for a third time, to Mariamne II, after a -year hiatus from family life (after putting to death his 2nd wife Mariamne I).
Augustus founds the city of Nicopolis in Egypt to commemorate his final victory over Mark Antony.
August – The Han dynasty is restored in China as Liu Xiu proclaims himself Emperor Guangwu of Han, starting the Jianwu era.
Emperor Tiberius settles a dispute between Messenia and Sparta over the Ager Dentheliales on Mount Taygetus, awarding the land to Messenia.
November – Luoyang becomes the capital of the Houhan or Eastern Han dynasty.
Lucius Aelius Sejanus unsuccessfully attempts to marry Livilla.
Estimation: Rome, capital of the Roman Empire, becomes the largest city in the world, taking the lead from Chang'an, capital of China.
Imperator Caesar Augustus becomes Consul for the ninth time. His partner is Marcus Junius Silanus.
Galatia becomes a Roman province after the death of its king. The Roman troops stationed there are relocated to Egypt.
The temple to Neptune on the Circus Flaminius is built.
The government gives its tributary states, rolls of silk cloth and about, pounds of silk floss.
Romans crush an uprising of Thracian tribesmen.
Jesus is baptized in the Jordan River by John the Baptist and begins his public ministry, according to some scholars.
Pontius Pilate is appointed as prefect of Judea.
Emperor Tiberius retires to Capri, leaving the Praetorian Guard under Lucius Aelius Sejanus in charge of the Roman Empire and the city of Rome.

Imperator Caesar Augustus becomes Roman Consul for the eighth time. His partner Titus Statilius Taurus becomes Consul for the second time and refounds the old Contestanian Iberian capital of Ilici, known since then as "Colonia Iulia Ilici Augusta".
Abgar III of Osroene is succeeded by Abgar IV Sumaqa.
Disastrous campaign of Aelius Gallus in the Arabian Peninsula, then known as "Arabia Felix".
Gavius Silo, orator, is heard by Caesar Augustus - mentioned by Seneca.
Dioteimus Alaieus is one of the Archons of Athens.
A poorly built amphitheatre in Fidenae collapses, killing, of the, spectators.
An Arc of Triumph is erected in Rimini, in honor of the former Emperor Augustus.

Using the dates and ranges listed in the Gospel of Luke, this year can be established as when John the Baptist begins preaching in the Jordan. It is also likely that Jesus was baptised by John in the final months of this year before his temptation and the first of three Passovers listed in the Gospel of John.
Possible date of the Baptism of Jesus by John the Baptist (another possibility is ).
Agrippa divides Hispania Ulterior into Baetica and Lusitania, and enlarges Hispania Citerior.
Augustus' first census of the Roman Empire (formerly the Roman Republic) reports a total of,, citizens.
Marcus Agrippa begins the construction of the old Pantheon, Rome.
Caesar Augustus starts a new military reform. He reduces the number of legions to and creates the Praetorian Guard (, men).
Augustus forms the Classis Misenensis, based in the harbor of Portus Julius at Misenum.
Frisians revolt against Roman authorities, hanging tax collectors and besieging a local fort. Frisians achieve victory and gain considerable prestige among other local tribes.
Roman legions in Germania are transported by fleet to the fortress of Flevum on the Rhine, to operate against the rebellious Frisians.
King Daru of Baekje succeeds to the throne of Baekje in the Korean peninsula.
The Frisians negotiate a treaty with the Roman Empire at the River Rhine.
According to the Gospel of Luke (Luke :-), the ministries of John the Baptist and Jesus begin at the earliest in this year, and more likely in.
The Roman Senate grants Octavian Caesar imperium maius (supreme command) of the Roman armed forces (Around legions).
May – The earliest dated record of a sunspot by Chinese astronomers.
Gaius Julius Caesar Octavian becomes Roman Consul for the sixth time. His partner Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa becomes Consul for the second time.
Augustus initiates a census of the Roman Republic for the first time since.
According to the Gospel of Luke (Luke :-), the ministries of John the Baptist and Jesus is thought to have started this year. Jesus is baptized by John the Baptist.
Aulus Plautius, later military leader of the invasion of Britain under Emperor Claudius, becomes suffect consul alongside Lucius Nonius Asprenas.
Agrippina the Elder is exiled to the island of Pandataria, and her sons (except Caligula) are imprisoned by Lucius Aelius Sejanus.
Jesus executed by crucifixion, according to Roman Catholic tradition and Tertullian's chronology.
March – Horace writes the ode Occidit Daci Cotisonis agmen.
Start of the Cantabrian Wars against Roman occupation in Hispania.
Marcus Licinius Crassus campaigns successfully in the Balkans, killing the king of the Bastarnae by his own hand, but is denied the right to dedicate the spolia opima by Octavian.
Sofia, modern day capital of Bulgaria, is conquered by the Romans and becomes known as Ulpia Serdica.
Though started under the triumvirate with Mark Anthony and Marcus Lepidus, Octavian completes three projects in the Forum Romanum: Temple of the Deified Julius, the Curia, and the Chalcidicum.

Agrippina the Elder (the wife of Germanicus) and two of her sons, Nero Julius Caesar and Drusus Caesar, are arrested and exiled on orders of Lucius Aelius Sejanus (the prefect of the Praetorian Guard), and later starved to death in suspicious circumstances. In Sejanus's purge of Agrippina the Elder and her family, her son Caligula, and her three daughters, Agrippina the Younger, Julia Drusilla and Julia Livilla are the only survivors.
Phaedrus translates Aesop's fables, and composes some of his own.
April (Good Friday) – Jesus is crucified (according to one dating scheme). He is later reported alive by his disciples.
The Kushan Empire is founded (approximate date).
Velleius Paterculus writes the general history of the countries known in Antiquity.

Summer – Cornelius Gallus lands in Cyrene and occupies Paraetonium. Mark Antony storms the city walls and blockades the harbour, then retreats with his army to Egypt and receives the news that Pelusium has opened its gates to Octavian without resistance.
Spring – Octavian leads his army to the Dardanelles, ships them across to Asia Minor and marches into Syria where Herod the Great sends him vows of loyalty and thousands of his own troops in support.
Octavian claims Cleopatra's treasure in the mausoleum at the Taposiris Magna (Temple of Isis); he pays the salaries of his veteran legionaries and gives them land in Italy.
August – Octavian Caesar captures Alexandria. This marks the official annexation of Ancient Egypt to the Roman Republic.

August or – With the death of Cleopatra, probably by suicide, in Alexandria and the probable murder soon afterwards of her son and nominal co-ruler Caesarion, the Ptolemaic dynasty, the last of Ancient Egypt, comes to an end. The first year of Octavian's reign in Egypt.
Judea earthquake, earthquake mentioned in catalogues of historical earthquakes. It affected the Herodian Kingdom of Judea in the Holy Land.
Amyntas, king of Galatia, deserts with, cavalry to Octavian. One-third of Antony's oarsmen are lost to malnutrition, disease and desertion.
Antony, alerted by Octavian's presence, sets up camp on the southern shore, at the promontory of Actium. He dispatches a force to isolate the camp of Octavian in the valley of Louros.
The Egyptian fleet, including Cleopatra's treasure ship, retreats to Taenarus. Antony transfers his flag to a smaller vessel and breaks through Octavian's line.
Octavian crosses the Strait of Otranto and lands with an army at Panormus in Dalmatia. He marches to Toryne in the south, and establishes a bridgehead at the Gulf of Ambracia.

Sparta under Caius Iulius Eurycles, whose father Antony had been ordered to be executed for piracy, declares his support for Octavian. Lappa (modern Argyroupoli) in Attica and Kydonia in Crete revolt against Cleopatra.
Zacynthus is held by Gaius Sosius, and Methone by Bogud of the royal house of Mauretania, driven into exile by his brother Bocchus II.
Gnaeus Domitius Ahenobarbus and Gaius Sosius become consuls of Rome.
Winter – Antony distributes garrisons along the west coast of Greece, stations the fleet at Actium and establishes his headquarters at Patrae.

July – The Roman Senate declares war upon Mark Antony and Cleopatra VII. Octavian Caesar is proclaimed dux and the West - Gallic and Spanish provinces, Africa, Sicily and Sardinia - swear an oath of loyalty to him.
April – According to Colin Humphrey's account, Jesus of Nazareth's Last Supper takes place.
A financial crisis hits Rome, due to poorly chosen fiscal policies. Land values plummet, and credit is increased.
Emperor Tiberius founds a credit bank in Rome.

Although the usurpation of Wang Mang and the Chimei Rebellion are behind him, Emperor Guangwu now faces a new threat to the Han dynasty: the Rebellion of Gongsun Shu in the Sichuan province. Gongsun's naval forces are unsuccessful against Han General Cen Peng, so Gongsun decides to fortify his position by blockading the entire Yangtze River with a large floating pontoon bridge, complete with floating fortified posts.
The second term of the Second Triumvirate expires.
Mark Antony annexes the kingdom of Media and arranges the marriage of his son Alexander Helios with princess Iotapa, the daughter of king Artavasdes I.
Gaius Julius Caesar Octavian becomes consul for the second time. His partner is Lucius Volcatius Tullus.
The Kinambroi surrender to Octavian.
Crown Prince Ao ascends to the throne as Emperor Cheng of Han of the Han dynasty.
Stephen, one of the original seven deacons of the Christian Church, is martyred for his faith (possible date).
Naevius Sutorius Macro gains favour in the Roman Empire by prostituting his wife Ennia Thrasylla to Caligula.
Rome intervenes in Armenia ( –).
Saul of Tarsus, on the road to Damascus, is converted to Christianity, and becomes Paul the Apostle (possible date).
The Roman aqueduct Pont du Gard is constructed, running for km, ending at Nîmes (approximate date).
Mark Antony becomes Roman Consul for the second time. His partner is Lucius Scribonius Libo.
Antony advances into Armenia with an expeditionary force and marches to the capital Artaxata. He arrests king Artavasdes II and takes him to Alexandria.

Autumn – The Donations of Alexandria: Antony distributes the eastern kingdoms as a gift to the children of Cleopatra VII of Egypt; he declares Caesarion, Caesar's illegitimate son, as co-ruler of Egypt and Cyprus. Alexander Helios receives Armenia and Media; to Cleopatra Selene II he gives the kingdoms of Cyrenaica and Libya.

Gaius Julius Caesar Octavian pacifies Dalmatia and Pannonia forming the province of Illyricum, while Antony regains Armenia from Parthia. Octavian reduces the outposts defending the Liburnian town of Promona, sets up siege works and forces its surrender.
Pliny the Elder is brought to Rome before this year.
Tiridates III becomes king of Parthia.
Emperor Tiberius names Caligula (aka Gaius) and Gamellus, a grandson, as co-heirs.
Illyria becomes a Roman province. Gaius Julius Caesar Octavian conducts a rendezvous with the Roman fleet under Agrippa, which is engaged in clearing the Dalmatian coast of piracy.
Marcus Titius arrives in Syria with a large army and marches to Asia Minor. Sextus is caught in Miletus and executed without trial.
Azes I, Indo-Scythian ruler, completes the domination of the Scythians in northern India.

Phraates IV ascended the Parthian throne after eliminating his father Orodes II and several royal rivals. The Mahestan (the noble council of the Parthian Empire) initially opposed his rise due to concerns about his violent methods.
Pannonia is attacked by Octavian Caesar, who conquers and sacks the stronghold Siscia of the Segestani, which is taken after a -day siege. The country is not definitely subdued, however, until.
Marcellus becomes governor of Judaea and Samaria.
December – Wu Han commands the forces of Emperor Guang Wu of the Eastern Han to conquer the separatist Chengjia Empire, reuniting China.
Lucius Vitellius defeats Artabanus III of Parthia in support of another claimant to the throne, Tiridates III.

Herod Antipas suffers major losses in a war with Aretas IV of Nabatea, provoked partly by Antipas' divorce of Aretas' daughter. According to Josephus, Herod's defeat was popularly believed to be divine punishment for his execution of John the Baptist.
Pontius Pilate is recalled to Rome, after putting down a Samaritan uprising.
Antony crosses the frontier into Media Atropatene and commences the siege of Phraaspa. He establishes a line of circumvallation and builds siege engines.

August – Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa, an admiral of Octavian Caesar, secures the Lipari Islands and harasses the coast from Mylae to Tyndaris. Octavian transports his legions, via Leucopetra, to Tauromenium (modern Taormina).

October – Antony abandons the siege of Phraaspa (near Maragheh, Iran). He retreats, loses many men to disease and starvation in the subsequent retreat to Egypt, and marries Cleopatra VII while still married to Octavia.
Publius Canidius Crassus invades Armenia and Iberia ; he forces Parnavaz II into an alliance against Zober, king of Albania.
Judea: Aristobulus III, the last of the Hasmoneans, becomes High Priest in Jerusalem, replacing Ananelus, who has only held the position for one year.
Peter the Apostle founds the Church of Antioch (approximate date).

March – The Roman Senate annuls Tiberius's will, and proclaims Caligula as Roman Emperor, nullifying the joint claim of Tiberius Gemellus. Caligula's attempt to have himself deified creates friction between himself and the Senate.

October – Caligula becomes seriously ill, or perhaps is poisoned. He recovers from his illness, but Caligula turns toward the diabolical: he starts to kill off those who are close to him, whom he sees as a serious threat.
Abilene is granted to King Agrippa I.
The Pharisee Saul of Tarsus is converted to Christianity, after a vision. After the year, he is recognised as Saint Paul.
Caesar Augustus engineers the "Second Pact of Tarentum" which renews the Triumvirate for an additional five years. Mark Antony exchanges ships, for service against Sextus Pompeius.
Antony reorganizes Asia Minor under strongmen loyal to him. He raises troops from his allies: Amyntas and Archelaus, kings of Galatia and Cappadocia.
The kingdom of Goguryeo in Korea is founded by the king Dongmyeong. (traditional date).

Agrippa creates the harbour "Portus Julius" in the today-submersed town of Puteoli (the modern Pozzuoli, close to Naples). The port is used to train the warships for naval battles, and a new fleet is built, with, oarsmen gathered by freeing slaves.

Romans conquer Jerusalem from the Parthians. Herod the Great becomes king of Judea and Ananelus is installed as High Priest; both positions are seized from Antigonus II Mattathias after a five-month siege.
Andrew the Apostle becomes the first patriarch of Constantinople, and resigns that position shortly thereafter.
Phaedrus writes his popular collection of fables.
An anti-Jewish riot breaks out in Alexandria, during a visit by King Herod Agrippa I; the mob wants to place statues of Caligula in every synagogue.

Paul meets Peter and James in Jerusalem (approximate date) (After some years "from his vision on the road to Damascus " went to Jerusalem to meet Peter and stayed days with him.(Epistle to Galatians chapter a ).
Stachys the Apostle becomes the second patriarch of Constantinople.
January – Beginning of the Hispanic era.

Octavian appoints Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa governor of Transalpine Gaul, where he puts down an uprising of the Aquitanians. He also fights successfully against the Germanic tribes, and becomes the next Roman general to cross the Rhine after Julius Caesar.

January – Octavian marries Livia while she is still pregnant from a recently broken marriage. Octavian gained permission from the College of Pontiffs to wed her while she is still pregnant from another husband.
Caligula's campaign into Germany is stopped by a conspiracy led by Cassius Chaerea. Even though he never even reaches Germany, Caligula proclaims himself victorious and orders a triumph.
Gaius Caesar Augustus Germanicus and Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo become Roman consuls.
Caligula orders a floating bridge to be built using ships as pontoons, stretching for two miles from Baiae to the neighboring port of Puteoli.
Tigellinus, minister and favorite of the later Roman emperor Nero, is banished for adultery with Caligula's sisters.
Legio XV Primigenia and XXII Primigenia are levied by Caligula for the German frontier.

Sextus Pompey, styles himself "son of Neptune", controls Sicily, Sardinia, Corsica and the Peloponnesus, and is recognized by the Triumvirate in the Pact of Misenum. The pact helps to assure Rome's grain supply, and the blockade on Roman Italy is lifted.
Publius Ventidius defeats Pharnastanes with his cataphracts at the Amanus Gates, and goes on to reclaim Syria, Phoenicia and Judea. Labienus flees to Cilicia, where he is captured and executed.
Marcus Antonius dispatches Publius Ventidius Bassus with legions to the East and drives Quintus Labienus out of Asia Minor. Labienus retreats into Syria, where he receives Parthian reinforcements.
Noricum and Mauretania are incorporated into the Roman Empire.
Vardanes I becomes king of Parthia, opposed by his brother Gotarzes II.
The traditional date of Saint James the Great meeting Our Lady of the Pillar in Spain.
The Germanic Quadi tribe begin settling in present-day Moravia and Slovakia.
The Vietnamese Trưng Sisters rebel against the rule of the Chinese Emperor Guang Wu of Han.
Quintus Labienus occupies Cilicia and marches, with an army, into Anatolia. Most cities surrender without resistance, except for Alabanda and Mylasa.
Mark Antony leaves Alexandria. After receiving news of the outcome at Perusia while en route to Phoenicia, he sets sail for Italy meeting the ambassadors of Sextus Pompey in Athens.
The Ji Jiu Pian dictionary, published about this year during the Han dynasty, is the earliest known reference to the hydraulic-powered trip hammer device.
Parthians conquer Jerusalem. Hyrcanus II is removed from power, while Antigonus the Hasmonean becomes king of Judea under Parthian rule.
Sextus' fleet raids the ports of Puteoli and Ostia. The populace hold the Triumvirs responsible for prolonging the war, provoking a riot on the Forum.
An attack across the Rhine by the Germans is stopped by the Romans.
Messalina, wife of Claudius, persuades Claudius to have Seneca the Younger banished to Corsica on a charge of adultery with Julia Livilla.
Claudius succeeds his nephew, Caligula, as emperor.
Claudius makes Agrippa king of Judea.
January – After a night of negotiation, Claudius is accepted as emperor by the Senate.
Lucius Antonius occupies Perusia. He accepts the appeal of the local population.
Consuls: Lucius Antonius and Publius Servilius Vatia Isauricus.
Perusine War: An armed resistance breaks out across Italy; the Umbrian city of Sentinum is captured and destroyed by Quintus Salvidienus Rufus.
Mark Antony meets Cleopatra VII in Tarsus and forms an alliance. He returns to Alexandria with her and they become lovers in the winter of –.
Traditional date of foundation of the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria by the apostle Mark the Evangelist.
Dalmatian legate Lucius Arruntius Camillus Scribonianus revolts, but his troops defect, and his rebellion quickly withers.
The territories of the current Algeria and Morocco become a Roman province.
Romans take control of Ceuta, a port city on the North African side of the Strait of Gibraltar.
Claudius begins construction of Portus, a harbour bearing a lighthouse on the right bank of the Tiber.
August – Lucius Decidius Saxa and Gaius Norbanus Flaccus are appointed by Mark Antony, to lead an advanced force of eight legions to Macedonia along the Via Egnatia into Thrace.
Brutus and Cassius advance to Philippi and build fortifications. Antony links up with Norbanus and Saxa at Amphipolis, Octavian arrives on a litter days later.
In Sicily, Sextus Pompeius leads the naval operations in the Mediterranean Sea against the triumvirs. He blockades the grain routes from Spain and Africa.
Saxa retreats to link up with Norbanus at the Sapaei Pass. The Republicans outflank the enemy, forging an alternate route through the mountains in the north.
September – Brutus and Cassius cross the Hellespont. They march to Doriscus but further progress is blocked by Saxa's occupation of the Corpili Pass.
Warfare begins between the northern and southern Huns.
Julia Livia, daughter of Drusus Julius Caesar, is executed at the instigation of Claudius' wife Messalina.

May – Aulus Plautius, crossing from Boulogne in the Classis Britannica, lands with four Roman legions (, men) and the same number of auxiliaries at Rutupiae (probably modern Richborough) on the east coast of Kent. General (future emperor) Vespasian plays a major role in the defeat of the Britons led by the brothers Caratacus and Togodumnus (leaders of the Catuvellauni) in the -day Battle of the Medway (probably at the river near Rochester) and the Romans drive them back to and across the River Thames; Togodumnus dies soon after.
Vespasian begins to subdue the south-west.
The warrior Trung Sisters commit suicide after their resistance is defeated at Nam Viet.
July–August – Antony is again at the head of a large army; Octavian enters Rome in force without opposition. It is clear that Cicero's plan to divide them against each other has failed.

April – Battle of Forum Gallorum: Mark Antony, besieging Caesar's assassin Decimus Brutus Albinus in Mutina, defeats the forces of the consul Pansa, but is then immediately defeated by the army of the other consul, Hirtius. Both consuls are killed (Hirtius does not die until after the Battle of Mutina).
April – Octavian is first proclaimed imperator by his troops.

November – Octavian meets Antony and Lepidus in Bononia and the three enter into an official five-year autocratic pact, the Second Triumvirate (see lex Titia). To cement their reconciliation Octavian agrees to marry Claudia, a daughter of Antony's wife Fulvia by her former husband Publius Clodius Pulcher.
Mount Okmok volcano in the Aleutian Islands erupts with a volcanic explosivity index of, with climatic effects extending as far as Egypt.
The Isle of Rhodes returns to the Roman Empire.
(Approximate date, may be as late as ) A famine takes place in Judea.
Pomponius Mela writes De situ orbis, a geography of the Earth.
Minjung becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
Mauretania becomes a Roman province.
April –April – Octavian engages in a charm offensive with consular Cicero who is fulminating against Mark Antony.
December – Antony besieges Brutus Albinus in Mutina, with Octavian, an ally of Decimus, who is one of his uncle's assassins, close by.
Pharaoh Cleopatra VII of Egypt declares her son co-ruler as Ptolemy XV Caesarion.
The first of Cicero's Philippicae (oratorical attacks) on Antony is published. He will make of them over the next several months.
Comosicus succeeds Burebista as king of Dacia.
Claudius founds Savaria, today the Hungarian city of Szombathely.
Chinese general Ma Yuan conducts an expedition against the Xiongnu and the Xianbei (in Manchuria).
The Senate holds consultations regarding real estate speculation in Rome.
Emperor Claudius expels the Jews from Rome (estimated date, more probably later, - ).
Paul of Tarsus begins his missionary travels, according to one traditional dating scheme.
January – The Julian calendar takes effect as the civil calendar of the Roman Empire, establishing a solar calendar that is based on the Egyptian calendar of the day.
Fourth consulship of Gaius Julius Caesar (without colleague).
Caesar probably writes his Commentaries in this year.

March – Civil War: In his last victory, Julius Caesar defeats the Pompeian forces of Titus Labienus and Pompey the younger in the Battle of Munda. Labienus dies in battle, Pompey the younger is executed, but Sextus Pompey escapes to take command of the remnants of the Pompeian fleet.

The veterans of Julius Caesar's Legions Legio XIII Gemina and Legio X Equestris demobilize. The veterans of the 10th legion are settled in Narbo, while those of the 13th are given somewhat better lands in Italia itself.
A large famine occurred across Syria, recorded by Orosius, Suetonius, Tacitus and Josephus, due to bad harvests.
The settlement at Celje gets municipal rights, and is named municipium Claudia Celeia.
A census shows that there are more than,, Roman citizens.
After the death of its king, Thracia becomes a Roman province.
Dobruja is annexed into Roman Moesia.
Julius Caesar establishes Julia Paterna Arelate as a colony in Gaul for veterans of the Sixth Legion, at the present day site of Arles.
Caesar appoints his nephew Octavian his heir.

April – Caesar defeats the combined army of Pompeian followers and Numidians under Metellus Scipio and Juba I of Numidia at Thapsus. After the battle Caesar grants Legio V Alaudae the right to bear the elephant symbol on its shields and standards, for bravery against a charge of elephants.
Caesar subdues a mutiny of his Tenth Legion.
Caesar reforms the Roman calendar to create the Julian calendar. The transitional year is extended to 445 days to synchronize the new calendar and the seasonal cycle.
Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo is made commander of the Roman army in Germania Inferior. He conquers the Chauci and fights against the Cherusci and Frisians.
Cauci pirates led by the Roman deserter Gannascus ravage the Gallic coast; Corbulo uses the Rhine fleet against them. The Frisian revolt is suppressed.
Ananias becomes high priest in Judaea.
Corbulo orders the construction of the canal Fossa Corbulonis, between the Rhine and Meuse in the Netherlands, which connects the city Forum Hadriani.
Claudius founds the city Forum Claudii Vallensium (modern Martigny) in the Alpes Poeninae.
October – Caesar's invasion of Africa, against Metellus Scipio and Labienus, Caesar's former lieutenant in Gaul.

Battle at Mount Tabor in Judea: Roman troops, commanded by Gabinius, defeat the forces of Alexander, son of Aristobulus II of Judea, who is attempting to re-establish Judean independence. Some, Jews die at the hands of the Romans.
Consuls: Quintus Fufius Calenus, Publius Vatinius.
August – Julius Caesar leads victory against Pharnaces II of Pontus and at the Battle of Zela.
Civil War: August – Julius Caesar leads victory against Pharnaces II of Pontus and at the Battle of Zela. August – Julius Caesar quells a mutiny of his veterans in Rome.
Paul of Tarsus through his first mission goes to Cyprus and Asia Minor.
Emperor Guang Wu of Han, restores Chinese domination of Inner Mongolia. The Xiongnu are made confederates and guard the Northern border of the empire.
Gallic nobles are admitted to the Roman Senate. Claudius grants the rights of citizenship to the Aedui.

Publius Ostorius Scapula, governor of Britain, announces his intention to disarm all Britons south and east of the Trent and Severn. The Iceni, an independent, allied kingdom within that area, revolt but are defeated.
Mobon becomes ruler of the Korean kingdom of Goguryeo.
October – Julius Caesar reaches Alexandria, a city founded by Alexander the Great. He is met by an Egyptian delegation from Ptolemy XIII.
March – Mark Antony joins Julius Caesar.
Winter – Siege of Oricum: Julius Caesar captures the strategic city port of Oricum in Epirus (modern Albania). The garrison opens the town's gate and Lucius Manlius Torquatus surrenders to Caesar.
April – Siege of Dyrrhachium: Julius Caesar builds a fortified line of entrenchments and besieges Pompey the Great.
Caesar's Civil War: January – Julius Caesar lands at Dyrrhachium. March – Mark Antony joins Julius Caesar.
Agrippina the Younger charges Octavia's first fiancé Lucius Junius Silanus Torquatus with incest. He is brought before the Senate, and sentenced to death.
Christianity spreads into Europe, especially at Rome and at Philippi (probable date according to chronology derived from the Acts of the Apostles).
Melankomas is the boxing champion, at the 207th Olympic Games.
Nero becomes engaged to Claudia Octavia, daughter of Claudius.
Likely date for the expulsion of the Jews from Rome.
Consuls: Lucius Cornelius Lentulus Crus, Gaius Claudius Marcellus.
September – Brutus defeats the combined Pompeian-Massilian naval forces of the siege of Massilia, while the Caesarian fleet in the Adriatic Sea is defeated near Curicta.
April – Siege of Massilia: Caesar commences a siege at Massilia against the Pompeian Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus. He leaves the newly raised legions XVII, XVIII and XIX to conduct the siege.
June – Cicero slips out of Italy and goes to Thessaloniki.
September – Massilia surrenders to Caesar, as he is coming back from Spain.
In Judaea, a Roman soldier seizes and burns a Torah scroll. Procurator Cumanus has the culprit beheaded, calming down the Jews and delaying for almost two decades the outbreak of their revolt.
Diogenes, the Greek explorer, discovers the African Great Lakes.
Paul travels to Philippi, Thessaloniki, Veroia, and Athens (second missionary journey).
Christianity is introduced throughout Nubia by a high official of Queen Judith.
Hero of Alexandria invents a steam turbine (possible date).
The Senate recalls Julius Caesar and rescinds his authority. Caesar breaks alliance with Pompey.
Initiation Rites of the Cult of Bacchus, detail of a wall painting in the Villa of the Mysteries, Pompeii, is made (approximate date).
Consuls: Lucius Aemilius Paullus and Gaius Claudius Marcellus.
The Roman Republic takes control of Judea (approximate date).
The Roman artillery piece called Scorpio is invented.
Emperor Claudius and future emperor Titus Flavius Vespasianus are Roman Consuls.
Burrus, praetorian prefect (– ), charges Seneca with the education of Nero.

The captured Caratacus is exhibited in chains in Claudius' triumph in Rome, but his dignified demeanour persuades the emperor to spare his life and allow his family to live free in the capital for a short period of time.

In Britain, governor Publius Ostorius Scapula defeats Caratacus and the Silures in the territory of the Ordovices in central Wales. Caratacus seeks sanctuary with Cartimandua, queen of the Brigantes in northern England, but she is a Roman ally and hands him over to Ostorius.
Vonones II dies a few months after he had ascended to the throne. His son Vologases I becomes the new Parthian king.
Spring – King Ptolemy XII dies and is succeeded by his eldest surviving daughter Cleopatra VII and her younger brother Ptolemy XIII as co-rulers of the Ptolemaic Kingdom.
Consuls: Marcus Claudius Marcellus and Servius Sulpicius Rufus.
Pompey demands that Julius Caesar lay down his command before he can stand for consul.
The Xiongnu split into two hordes. The Eastern horde is subject to China.
Pliny the Elder writes his account of the German wars.
In Rome a law prohibits the execution of old and crippled slaves.
Barea Soranus is consul suffectus in Rome.

Saint Thomas, one of the twelve disciples of Jesus, is believed to have landed in Kodungallur, India to preach the Gospel; the Marthoma Church, the Syro-Malabar Catholic Church, the Malankara Mar Thoma Syrian Church, the Indian Orthodox Church, and the Assyrian Church of the East claim descent from him.
Ananias, a high priest in Jerusalem, is sent to Rome after being accused of violence.
March – Siege and capture of Avaricum.
Winter – Julius Caesar crosses Mons Cevenna (central Gaul) and sends his army through the passes covered with snowdrifts to take the rebellious Arverni by surprise.
Milo is tried for the murder of Clodius. Despite Cicero's legal defence (Pro Milone) he is found guilty and exiled in Massilia (modern Marseille).
Gnaeus Pompeius marries Cornelia Metella.

September – Battle of Alesia: Julius Caesar defeats the Gallic allies coming to aid Vercingetorix, led by his cousin Vercassivellanus. Vercingetorix surrenders on October, signalling the Roman conquest of Gaul.
Decimus Junius Silanus Torquatus and Quintus Haterius Antoninus become Roman consuls.
Cardiff is founded by Aulus Didius Gallus.
Paul the Apostle writes his epistle to the Galatians from Ephesus (approximate date).
Tiridates I, brother of Vologases I, comes to power in Armenia as an adversary of the Romans.
Seneca writes the tragedy Agamemnon, which he intends to be read as the last chapter of a trilogy including two of his other tragedies, Medea and Edipus.
Vercingetorix, an Arverni chieftain, leads a revolt against Caesar in Central Gaul.
Winter – Caesar enrolls non-citizen soldiers in Gallia Transalpina, genesis of Legio V Alaudae. He increases his army to ten legions.
Gallic War: Julius Caesar suppresses a revolt led by Ambiorix near Sabis (Northern Gaul). At Cenabum (modern Orléans) Roman merchants are massacred by the Carnutes.

Parthian War: Crassus sacks the Temple of Hierapolis and the Temple in Jerusalem on his way to engage the Parthians. May – Battle of Carrhae: Romans defeated, and Crassus killed, by Parthians led by General Surena.
Julius Caesar suppresses a revolt led by Ambiorix near Sabis (Northern Gaul).
Patriarch Onesimus succeeds Stachys the Apostle as Patriarch of Constantinople.
Judea is returned piecemeal to Herod Agrippa's son Marcus Julius Agrippa between and.

Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo arrives in the East and takes up an assignment as governor of Asia, with a secret brief from Nero and his chief ministers, Seneca and Burrus, to return Armenia to the Roman Empire.
Corbulo recruits Syrian auxiliary units in the region and stations them in border forts, with orders from Nero not to provoke the Parthians.
Paul of Tarsus begins his third mission.
Crassus arrives in Syria as proconsul and invades the Parthian Empire, initiating the Roman–Persian Wars, which were to last nearly seven centuries.
Winter – Ambiorix revolts in Gaul. He joins with Catuvolcus in an uprising against the Roman army.

Fifth year of Julius Caesar's Gallic Wars: July – Second of Caesar's Invasions of Britain: Julius Caesar receives nominal submission from the tribal chief Cassivellaunus and installs Mandubracius as a friendly king. Winter – Ambiorix revolts in Gaul.
Pompey builds the first permanent theatre in Rome.
Octavia the Younger and Gaius Claudius Marcellus marry.
The apostle Paul writes his First Epistle to the Corinthians.
Emperor Nero becomes a Roman Consul.
The Roman jurist Sabinus writes three books on the rights of citizens.
June – Julius Caesar crosses the Rhine River near modern-day Koblenz. He constructs a wooden bridge between Andernach and Neuwied.

Summer – Julius Caesar defeats the Usipetes and the Tencteri, two Germanic tribes who have been driven across the Rhine River by the Suebi. He spreads Roman law and order, and makes the whole country as far as the Channel accessible to trade.
Consuls: Marcus Licinius Crassus and Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus.
Consuls Marcus Licinius Crassus and Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus pass the Lex Trebonia.
Spring – Julius Caesar starts the season campaigning in Illyricum (in the Balkan region) against the Pirustae, who have been raiding Roman territory.
War between Rome and Parthia breaks out due to the invasion of Armenia by King Vologases I, who has replaced the Roman-supported ruler with his brother Tiridates I of Armenia. (approximate date).
Publius Clodius Thrasea Paetus becomes a consul in Rome.
The Jianwu era of the Eastern Han dynasty changes to the Jianwuzhongyuan era.
The apostle Paul writes his second Epistle to the Corinthians, probably from Philippi.
The apostle Paul writes his Epistle to the Romans, from Corinth.

This year, or possibly the following year, the king of the Trinovantes called Imanuentius, is overthrown and killed by his rival Cassivellaunus. His son Mandubracius flees to Gaul and appeals to Julius Caesar for help.

The three Roman politician-generals of the First Triumvirate — Caesar, Pompey and Crassus — meet at the Luca Conference at the town of Luca (modern Lucca, in Tuscany), near Pisa, where they renewed their fraying political alliance, and further cemented the three men's increasing consolidation of power in the Roman Republic.
Autumn – Julius Caesar leads an attack on the Morini and the Menapii tribes of the Belgae on the North Sea. They withdraw into their forests, creating difficulties for Caesar's supply lines.
Clodia accuses her former lover Marcus Caelius Rufus of trying to poison her. The trial ends with the defendant acquitted thanks to the Pro Caelio speech of Cicero.

Third year of Julius Caesar's Gallic Wars: Battle of Morbihan: Decimus Junius Brutus Albinus, one of Caesar's subordinates, defeats the Veneti of Brittany. The Gauls lose most of their warships to the Romans in a sea battle at modern-day Quiberon Bay.
Envoys from Cilicia come to Rome to accuse their late governor, Cossutianus Capito, of extortion; the Roman Senate is supported in the case by Publius Clodius Thrasea Paetus.
Also in Britain Venutius begins his rebellion against his wife Cartimandua.
Paul of Tarsus writes his Second Epistle to the Corinthians and his Epistle to the Romans (probable date).
March – Guang Wu dies after a -year reign and is succeeded by his son Han Mingdi.
Emperor Nero becomes a Roman consul again.
Consuls: Publius Cornelius Lentulus Spinther and Quintus Caecilius Metellus Nepos.
May – Battle of the Axona: Caesar defeats the forces of the Belgae under King Galba of the Suessiones.
September – The siege and capture of Aduatuca (modern-day Tongeren) by Caesar.
Bak Hyeokgeose becomes the first ruler of the kingdom of Silla (traditional date).
Spring – Julius Caesar raises a further two legions (Legio XIII and Legio XIV), bringing his army in Gaul to eight legions (at which strength it remains until ).
Emperor Nero and Marcus Valerius Messalla Corvinus become Roman consuls.
Agrippina the Younger, conspired with the senators in late to overthrow Nero.
In Thuringia conflict between two Germanic tribes erupts over access to water.

Agrippina the Younger is expelled from the imperial palace by her son Nero, who installs her in Villa Antonia in Misenum, and leaving more of the effective and real power of Empire in the hands of Nero.
Gnaeus Julius Agricola, some years old, is serving as a military tribune in Britain under Gaius Suetonius Paulinus and is attached to Legio II Augusta.

Julius Caesar becomes a provincial governor and leads a Roman army ( Roman legions; Legio VII, Legio VIII, Legio IX, Legio X, and newly levied Legio XI and Legio XII) into Gaul. He deploys auxiliaries as part of this army, including Balearic slingers, Numidian and Cretan archers, and Celtic/Gallic cavalry (such as the allied Aedui).
Publius Clodius Pulcher, Roman tribune, institutes a monthly corn dole for poor Romans, and exiles Cicero from the city.
Base year of the Vikrama Era, founded by Vikrama, king of Ujjain in India.
Cyprus becomes a Roman province.
Berenice IV becomes queen of Egypt after temporarily dethroning her father, King Ptolemy XII Auletes.
March – Emperor Nero orders the murder of his mother Agrippina the Younger. He tries to kill her through a planned shipwreck, but when she survives, he has her executed and frames it as a suicide.
An eclipse on April over North Africa is recorded by Pliny the Elder in his Natural History.
Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo, Roman commander in the east, captures Tigranocerta in Mesopotamia. He installs Tigranes VI, a Cappadocian prince, as ruler of Armenia.
Publius Clodius Thrasea Paetus retires from the Roman Senate. He openly shows his disgust at the behaviour of Nero regarding the murder of Agrippina.
In the Satyricon, Petronius pokes fun at Roman immorality.
The First Triumvirate: Caesar, Pompey and Crassus form an unofficial alliance.
Caesar marries Calpurnia, in Rome.
Caesar makes the gazette Acta Diurna (Daily News) public. The Acta contains details of official decrees and appointments; births, deaths, and marriages.

Consuls: Gaius Julius Caesar and Marcus Calpurnius Bibulus (known in jest as "the consulship of Julius and Caesar" due to Bibulus' Social withdrawal from public view to "consult the heavens" in an effort to invalidate Caesar's intended legislation).
The colonia of Florentia, modern Florence, founded.
Vitellius is proconsul of the province of Africa.
Paul of Tarsus journeys to Rome, but is shipwrecked on Malta. He stays for three months and converts Publius, the first bishop of Malta.

Prasutagus, king of the Iceni (modern East Anglia), dies leaving a will which passes his kingdom to his two daughters and the Roman Empire. The Roman army, however, annexes the kingdom as if conquered, depriving the nobles of their hereditary lands and plundering the land.
The Roxolani are defeated on the Danube by the Romans.
Nero's exploration of the Nile: Emperor Nero sends an expedition which reaches the historical city Meroë. (approximate date).
Creation of the First Triumvirate, an informal political alliance between Julius Caesar, Pompey the Great and Marcus Licinius Crassus.
Gaius Julius Caesar suppresses an uprising and conquers all of Lusitania for Rome.
The Seleucid Empire comes to an end with the last two emperors being murdered on orders from Rome.
The Han dynasty government establishes the Protectorate of the Western Regions, the highest military position of a military commander on the Western frontier (Tarim Basin).

Prasutagus, king of the Iceni (modern East Anglia), dies leaving a will which passes his kingdom to his two daughters and the Roman Empire. The Roman army however annexes the kingdom as if conquered, depriving the nobles of their hereditary lands and plundering the land.

Boudica leads a rebellion of the Iceni against Roman rule in alliance with the Trinovantes, Cornovii, Durotriges and Celtic Britons. The Iceni and Trinovantes first destroy the Roman capital Camulodunum, wipe out the infantry of the Legio IX Hispana (commanded by Quintus Petillius Cerialis) and go on to burn Londinium (probably destroying London Bridge) and Verulamium (St Albans), in all cases massacring the inhabitants in their thousands.
Publius Petronius Turpilianus and Lucius Caesennius Paetus become Roman consuls.
Galba becomes governor of Hispania Tarraconensis.

Battle of Watling Street: Paulinus defeats the rebels, using a flying wedge formation, and imposes wide-ranging punishments on native Britons, but is removed from office after an enquiry instituted by Gaius Julius Alpinus Classicianus (appointed procurator ) and the Romanisation of Britain continues. Boudica either poisons herself or falls sick and dies.
Pompey returns to Rome with a triumph in honor of his for victories in the eastern provinces.
Julius Caesar becomes governor in Hispania and creates Legio X Gemina (,500 men). He puts down the Callaici and Lusitani rebellions.
Marcus Pupius Piso Frugi as consul attempts to gain ratification of Pompey's Eastern Settlement.
A great earthquake damages cities in Campania, including Pompeii.
A violent storm destroys 200 ships anchored at Portus.

Vologases I leads the Parthian army in a full-scale assault on the Euphrates. Legio X Fretensis and men of the other two legions (Legio III Gallica and Legio VI Ferrata) defend the eastern bank of the river, fighting off a desperate attack.
Emperor Nero marries for the second time, to Poppaea Sabina, ex-wife of Marcus Salvius Otho.
Paul of Tarsus is released from imprisonment in Rome (approximate date).
January – The forces of the conspirator Catiline are defeated by the loyal Roman armies of Antonius Hybrida led by Marcus Petreius in the Battle of Pistoria.
Cicero delivers his Pro Archia Poeta in defense of Aulus Licinius Archias' claim to Roman citizenship.
Caesar and Bibulus are praetors.
Julius Caesar divorces Pompeia, following the sacrilege of Publius Clodius Pulcher.
Cato the Younger, as tribune, presents a lex frumentaria (enacting a grain dole).
Vespasian becomes governor of Africa (estimated year).
Aulus Cornelius Celsus writes a dictionary on the arts and sciences.
Gnaeus Domitius Corbulo is restored to command after the Roman debacle at the Battle of Rhandeia. He invades Armenia and defeats Tiridates I, who accepts Roman sovereignty.
According to legend, Joseph of Arimathea goes to Glastonbury on the first Christian mission to Britain.
Apostle Paul possibly visits Spain.
Pharnaces II becomes King of Pontus.
Pompey conquers the people of Phonecia, Coele-Syria, and Judea for the Roman Republic.
Cato the Younger is elected tribune of the people for, taking office in early December.
Julius Caesar is elected Pontifex Maximus and praetor for.
Second Catilinarian Conspiracy against the Roman Republic is foiled by Cicero.

July - – Great Fire of Rome: A fire begins which destroyed three of fourteen of the administrative regions of Rome, more commonly known as the Palatine hill, the Circus Maximus, and the Oppian hill. Also suffering severe damage were the Campus Martius and the Via Lata.
The Kushan sack the ancient town of Taxila (in modern-day Pakistan).
Lyon sends a large sum of money to Rome to aid in the reconstruction. However, during the winter of –, Lyon suffers a catastrophic fire itself, and Nero reciprocates by sending money to Lyon.
Persecution of Christians in Rome begins under Nero. Peter the Apostle is possibly among those crucified.
Seneca proclaims the equality of all men, including slaves.
King Antiochus XIII Asiaticus is deposed and killed by the Syrian chieftain Sampsiceramus I – this is considered by some the end of the Seleucid dynasty.
Pompey destroys the kingdom of Pontus; king Mithridates VI commits suicide after escaping to the Crimea.
Syria earthquake, mentioned in catalogues of historical earthquakes. It affected the region of Syria and may have caused structural damage in the city of Jerusalem.
Pompey annexes Syria and captures Jerusalem, annexing Judea.

After a stage performance in which he appears and shocks the senatorial class considerably, Nero engages in a series of reprisals against Seneca the Younger and Tigellinus, pro-republican senators, and anyone else he distrusts.
Paul writes his first epistle to Timothy in Corinth; afterwards, he goes to Nikopoli to spend the winter.
Paul of Tarsus ordains Timothy as bishop of Ephesus (traditional date).
Nero's pregnant wife, Poppea Sabina, dies from Nero kicking her stomach or while having a miscarriage.
April – The freedman Milichus betrays the Pisonian conspiracy led by Gaius Calpurnius Piso to kill Emperor Nero and all the conspirators are arrested.
In response to the illegal exercise of citizen rights by foreigners, the Roman Senate passes the Lex Papia, which expels all foreigners from Rome.
Tigranes of Armenia is defeated and captured by Pompey, thus ending all hostilities on the northeastern frontier of Rome.
Pompey the Great subjugates the kingdom of Iberia and makes Colchis a Roman province.
9th year of the reign of Emperor Xuan of Han.

Gallus leads his main force down the coast from Caesarea via Antipatris to Lydda, detaching other units, by land and sea, to neutralize the rebel strongholds at Joppa, Narbata and the Tower of Aphek. With Galilee and the entire Judean coast in his hands, Gallus assumes his campaign before the winter rains render the roads impassable.
The first and second Epistles to Timothy are written (speculative date, if actually written by St. Paul).
The Roman Legio II Augusta is stationed at Gloucester.
Suetonius Paullinus, governor of Britannia, becomes a Roman Consul.

Mid–late October – Cestius Gallus, legate of Syria, marches into Judea and leads a Roman army of, men to put down the Jewish rebellion. At its core is Legio XII Fulminata, plus, selected men from the other three Syrian legions, six more cohorts of infantry and four alae of cavalry, plus over, auxiliaries furnished by Rome's eastern allies, including Herod Agrippa II and two other client kings, Antiochus IV of Commagene and Sohaemus of Emesa, who lead their forces (largely archers and cavalry) in person.
Catiline accused of conspiring against the Roman Republic with Autronius and the younger Sulla (also in during the consulship of Cicero).
Consuls: Manius Aemilius Lepidus and Lucius Volcatius Tullus.
Tigranes II is forced to surrender, by a payment of, talents, and is reinstated by Pompey as a "friend of the Roman people" to hold Armenia as a buffer zone.
Cicero becomes praetor in Rome.
Aristobulus II becomes king and high priest of Judea, until.
The Jewish fortress of Gamla in the Golan falls to the Romans, and its inhabitants are massacred.
Siege of Yodfat: Its, Jewish inhabitants are massacred. The historian Josephus, leader of the rebels in Galilee, is captured by the Romans.
Linus succeeds Peter, as the second Bishop of Rome.
First Jewish–Roman War: Vespasian arrives in Ptolemais in Phoenicia along with the Legio X Fretensis and Legio V Macedonica, to put down the revolt.

Vespasian is joined by his son Titus, who brings Legio XV Apollinaris from Alexandria. By late spring the Roman army numbers more than, soldiers, including auxilia and troops of King Herod Agrippa II.
Julius Caesar marries Pompeia, a granddaughter of Sulla.
Hyrcanus II becomes king of Judea, for first time, upon the death of his mother, Salome Alexandra.
After his victory at Zela Mithridates starts consolidating his power in Pontus; restoring his rule over his old kingdom.
Pompey offers the ex-pirates and their families clemency, he settles them in agricultural colonies in eastern Mediterranean lands.
During Pompey's war against the pirates, he raises a fleet of 500 warships and fights with great success.
Ignatius of Antioch becomes the third bishop of Antioch.
Apostles Peter and Paul are martyred in Rome (latest possible date).
Trajan moves to Scythopolis and crosses the Jordan River with Legio X Fretensis. He lays siege to Jericho and destroys the monastery of Qumran, where the Dead Sea Scrolls are originated.
Final year that Tacitus records Annals, a written history of the Roman Empire.
The Essenes place the Dead Sea Scrolls in the caves at Qumran.
Ostia, the harbour city of Ancient Rome, is sacked by pirates. The port is set on fire and the consular war fleet is destroyed.
Abgar II becomes ruler of Osroene.
Consuls: Lucius Caecilius Metellus and Quintus Marcius Rex.
October – Lucius Lucullus defeats Tigranes II of Armenia in the Battle of Artaxata.
Tribune of the plebs Gaius Antius Restio passes the Lex Antia sumptuaria law forbidding Roman magistrates from attending banquets.
German warbands cross over to join the revolt and attack the fortress at Mainz.
July – two legions in Egypt, a legion in Syria, and a legion in Judea declare Vespasian emperor.
Marcus Trebellius Maximus, governor of Britannia, is forced to flee to Gaul after a mutiny of Legio XX Valeria Victrix at Deva Victrix.
July – Tiberius Julius Alexander orders his legions in Alexandria to swear allegiance to Vespasian as emperor.
The Batavians attack Roman forts on the Rhine frontier; Fectio and Traiectum (modern Utrecht) are destroyed.
Parthians and Romans re-establish Euphrates as a frontier.
Rhodes becomes a bulwark against pirates, the Rhodians are unable to suppress piracy in the Aegean Sea. Delos gets the status of a free port.
Gaius Julius Caesar is a quaestor in Spain.
Antiochus XIII Asiaticus is installed as king of Syria.
Consuls: Quintus Caecilius Metellus Creticus and Quintus Hortensius.

About April – Titus opens a full-scale assault on Jerusalem, concentrating his attack on the city's Third Wall (HaHoma HaShlishit) to the northwest. The Roman army begins trying to breach the wall using testudos, mantlets, siege towers, and battering rams.
August – Titus captures Jerusalem.
Roman legions V Alaudae and XV Primigenia are destroyed by the Batavi. Later, Quintus Petillius Cerialis puts down the Batavian rebellion of Gaius Julius Civilis.
Pentecost (Shavuot, 6th of Sivan, about June ) – Priests in the Temple in Jerusalem feel a quaking and hear "a sound as of a great multitude saying, Let us remove hence".
21st of Artemisios (about May or ) – A "certain prodigious and incredible phenomenon", "chariots and troops" seen running in the clouds around Jerusalem.
Phraates III becomes the king of Parthia.
Lucullus captures Sinop, then invades Armenia.
The office of censor is reinstated.
August – In Rome, Cicero prosecutes former governor Verres; Verres exiles himself to Marseille before the trial is over.

Titus is made praetorian prefect of the Praetorian Guard and receives pro-consular command and also tribunician power, all of which indicates that Vespasian will follow the hereditary tradition of succession.
Emperors Vespasian and Marcus Cocceius Nerva are Roman Consuls.
The Romans establish a fortress at York, as a base for their northern forces. Initially established solely for Legio IX Hispana, it expands later to include public housing, baths and temples.
Herodium, a Jewish fortress south of Jerusalem, is conquered and destroyed by Legio X Fretensis on their way to Masada.
Battle of Treves: Cerialis defeats Claudius Civilis, thus quelling the Batavian rebellion.
Third Servile War ends; Slave rebellion under leadership of Spartacus is crushed by a Roman army under Marcus Licinius Crassus. Slaves taken prisoner are crucified naked along the Via Appia.
Nessebar in modern-day Bulgaria comes under Roman rule.
Marcus Antonius is defeated by the Cretans, who have made an alliance with the pirates. He is compelled to concede a humiliating peace.

First Jewish–Roman War: The Roman army (Legio X Fretensis) under Sextus Lucilius Bassus lays siege to the Jewish garrison of Machaerus at the Dead Sea. After they capitulate, the Zealots are allowed to leave the fortress before it is destroyed.
The Romans lay siege to Masada, a desert fortress held by the Sicarii.
Antiochus IV of Syria is deposed by Emperor Vespasian.

Vespasian starts the building of the Colosseum; the amphitheatre is used for gladiatorial games and public spectacles, such as sea battles, re-enactments of famous battles, and dramas of Classical mythology.
Vespasian and Titus are Roman Consuls.

Battle of Cabira: Lucius Lucullus defeats King Mithridates VI and overruns Pontus. Mithridates flees to Armenia, ruled by his son-in-law Tigranes, who refuses to turn his father-in-law in to Lucius Lucullus.

On the Iberian Peninsula (part of the Roman Republic) rebel leader Quintus Sertorius is assassinated by some of his own lieutenants (lead by Marcus Perperna). Perperna takes command of the rebel army.

Summer – Spartacus and his followers defeat the Roman forces under Gnaeus Cornelius Lentulus Clodianus and Gellius, forcing the Roman legions to retreat in disarray. Both consuls are recalled to Rome in disgrace and relieved of their duties.
Perperna is defeated by Pompey the Great at the Battle of Osca, ending the Sertorian War in Spain.
The Suebi and other tribes under King Ariovistus invade Gaul.

Spring – The Roman governor Lucius Flavius Silva lays siege to Masada, the last outpost of the Jewish rebels following the end, in, of the First Jewish-Roman War (Jewish Revolt). The Roman army (Legio X Fretensis) surrounds the mountain fortress with a -mile long siege wall and builds a rampart of stones and beaten earth against the western approach.

February – The Chinese Han dynasty launches a major campaign against the Xiongnu, whom they confront in the Battle of Yiwulu in the Kumul oasis, an ultimate Han military victory led by General Dou Gu (d. ).
Titus Flavius Domitianus becomes Roman Consul.
Martial writes a satire on "military cowardice".
Ban Chao (Pan-Ch’ao), competing with the Xiongnu, imposes a Chinese protectorate on the kings of Lop Nor and Khotan in the Tarim Basin, with the aim of controlling the Silk Road.

Battle of Mount Vesuvius: Spartacus defeats a Roman militia force (, men) under Gaius Claudius Glaber. The rebel slaves spend the winter of – training, arming and equipping their new recruits, as well as expanding their raiding territory, which includes the towns of Nola, Nuceria, Thurii and Metapontum.

Third Servile War: Spartacus, a Thracian gladiator, escapes with around slave-gladiators from a gladiator school at Capua. They defeat a small Roman force and equip themselves with captured military equipment as well with gladiatorial weapons.

On the Iberian Peninsula (part of the Roman Republic) rebel leader Quintus Sertorius is assassinated by some of his own lieutenants (lead by Marcus Perperna). Perperna takes command of the rebel army.
Mesopotamia: The last known cuneiform text is written.
Chinese generals Dou Gu (Teou Kou) and Geng Bing (Keng Ping) take control of Turpan.
The Black Forest region is reattached to the Roman Empire.
Emperor Ming of Han appoints Chen Mu to the revived office of Protector of the Western Regions.
Emperor Vespasian and his son Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consuls.
Nicomedes IV, last king of Bithynia bequeaths his kingdom to the Roman Senate upon his death (/ ).
Third Mithridatic War: Battle of Cyzicus: Roman forces under Lucius Lucullus defeat the forces of Mithridates VI of Pontus.
Publius Servilius Vatia returns to Rome, where he has triumphed against the pirates in Anatolia, and is given the agnomen Isauricus.
Cyrene becomes a Roman province.
Marcus Antonius (father of Mark Antony), a praetor, receives wide-ranging powers and considerable resources to fight the pirates in the Mediterranean Sea.
Accession of Han Zhangdi of the Han dynasty.
Frontinus begins his conquest of Wales; Legio II Augusta is moved to the border of the River Usk.
Emperor Vespasian and his son Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consuls.
Vespasian fortifies Armazi for the Iberian king Mithridates I. The Alans raid the Roman frontier in Armenia.
The Temple of Peace, also known as the Forum of Vespasian, is built in Rome. The temple celebrates the conquest of Jerusalem and houses the Menorah from Herod's Temple.
In the Roman province of Hispania Ulterior a republican army under Quintus Caecilius Metellus Pius defeats an army of Sertorian rebels at the Battle of Italica.

At the Battle of Saguntum the republican forces on the Iberian Peninsula and the Sertorian rebels fight each other to a draw. Quintus Sertorius is forced to withdraw leaving the battlefield to Pompey and Metellus (the republican commanders).
In Rome, the tribune Quintus Opimius speaks out against Sullan restrictions on the tribunate, in orations noted for sarcasm against conservatives.
Julius Caesar travels to Rhodes to study under Apollonius Molon. On his way across the Aegean Sea, he is kidnapped by Cilician pirates and held prisoner in the Dodecanese islet of Pharmacusa.
In the Roman province of Hispania Citerior an army of Sertorian rebels under Quintus Sertorius himself defeats a republican army under Pompey the Great at the Battle of Sucro.
Emperors Vespasianus Augustus and Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consuls.

Governor Sextus Julius Frontinus subdues the Silures and other hostile tribes of Wales, establishing a fortress at Caerleon or Isca Augusta for Legio II Augusta, and makes a network of smaller forts for his auxiliary forces.
Chinese historian Ban Gu develops a theory of the origins of the universe.
Pope Anacletus I succeeds Pope Linus as the third pope of the Catholic Church (according to the official Vatican list).
First year of Jianchu era of the Chinese Han dynasty.
Salome Alexandra becomes queen of Judea, after the death of her husband, Alexander Jannaeus, until.
On the Iberian Peninsula, in the Roman province of Hispania Citerior, the rebel forces of Quintus Sertorius defeat the republican army of Pompey the Great at the Battle of Lauron.
The Third Dalmatian war ends with the capture of Salona by proconsul Gaius Cosconius and the victory of Rome.
Hyrcanus II becomes high priest of Jerusalem for the first time, on the death of his father, Alexander Jannaeus, until.
The Romans develop a simple method of distillation.
Pliny the Elder publishes the first ten books of Naturalis Historia.
Agricola subdues the Ordovices in Wales, and pursues the remnants of the tribe to Anglesey, the holy island of the Druids.
Winter – Agricola conquers Anglesey, and disperses his army to their winter quarters.
Gnaeus Julius Agricola is named governor of Britannia, a post he occupies until. He extends the Roman influence to the mouth of the River Clyde, and builds fortifications.

Pompeius marches along the Via Domitia through Gallia Narbonensis crossing the Pyrenees to Spain. He joins with Quintus Metellus Pius to suppress the revolt of Quintus Sertorius, but is at first unsuccessful.
The city of Tigranakert of Artsakh is built.

Marcus Aemilius Lepidus, Roman proconsul of Transalpine Gaul and leader of the Populares faction in the senate, is defeated by Quintus Lutatius Catulus at the Milvian bridge outside Rome. The remnants of the rebels are wiped out by Pompey in Etruria.
Lepidus, with some, troops, manages to escape to Sardinia. Soon afterwards he becomes ill and dies, his battered army, now under command by Marcus Perperna Vento, sails on to the Iberian Peninsula.
Emperor Kadphises of the Kushan Empire sends a delegation to Rome, to seek support against the Parthians.
The Chinese philosopher Wang Chong (Wang-Ch'ung) claims all phenomena have material causes.
Pacorus II becomes king of the Parthian Empire (r. –).
The Romans conquer the Ordovices, located in present-day northern Wales, as well as the Silures.
Gnaeus Julius Agricola replaces Sextus Julius Frontinus as governor of Roman Britain, which leads to the conquering of portions of Wales and northern England.
The Third Dalmatian war begins.
Julius Caesar returns to Rome after about two years of service in the army.

In Rome, Marcus Aemilius Lepidus becomes consul. He attempts to undermine the Sullan reforms, quarrels with his consular colleague, is sent to govern Transalpine Gaul, and initiates a rebellion against the Senate with his army there.
The Tabularium is built in the Forum.

The Senate sends Publius Servilius Vatia to Cilicia as governor, where he fights a successful campaign against the Piracy in southern Anatolia (Lycia, Pamphylia and Isauria), he is thereafter known by the agnomen Isauricus.
Vespasianus Augustus and Titus Caesar Vespasianus become Roman Consuls.
Chester is founded as a castrum or Roman fort with the name Deva Victrix. The fortress is built by Legio II Adiutrix and contains barracks, granaries, military baths and headquarters.

Roman conquest of Britain: Gnaeus Julius Agricola campaigns in Britain: Chester is founded as a castrum or Roman fort with the name Deva Victrix. The fortress is built by Legio II Adiutrix and contains barracks, granaries, military baths and headquarters.

August or c. October – Eruption of Mount Vesuvius: Mount Vesuvius erupts, destroying Pompeii, Herculaneum, Stabiae and Oplontis. The Roman navy (based at Misenum), commanded by Pliny the Elder, evacuates refugees.
A commission of scholars canonizes the text of works of Confucius and his school.
Ptolemy XII Auletes succeeds Ptolemy XI Alexander II to the throne of Egypt.
Meleager publishes his Garland, the earliest known anthology of Greek poetry.
Alexandria comes under Roman jurisdiction.

Battle of the Baetis River: A force of Populares exiles under Sertorius defeat the legal Roman army of Lucius Fulfidias in Hispania, starting the Sertorian War; Quintus Caecilius Metellus Pius takes command on behalf of Sulla.
