December 23 - In the Serbian parliamentary election an alliance of reformist parties achieves a landslide victory over the nationalists, paving the way for a government under Zoran Đinđić.
– : the "Priest-king torso" was sculpted at Mohenjo-Daro, part of the Indus Valley civilization.
The last woolly mammoth goes extinct on Wrangel island.
: Ancient Egypt: Pharaoh Mentuhotep IV died. End of Eleventh Dynasty.
Rock-cut tombs at Beni Hasan were made. Twelfth Dynasty.
Bronze Age began in north Ancient China.
July 2 – The world's first self-contained artificial heart is implanted in Robert Tools in the United States.
The NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft touches down in the "saddle" region of 433 Eros, a near-Earth object, becoming the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid.
December – Dasht-i-Leili massacre: Hundreds of Taliban prisoners are killed by the forces of Abdul Rashid Dostum.
Former Argentinian president Carlos Menem is arrested on suspicion of illegal arms sales.
January 22 – The insurgency in Macedonia begins when a police station is shelled by the National Liberation Army in Tearce, near the border with Kosovo.
April 4 – A peace agreement is made to end the Angolan Civil War.
May 24 – United States President George W. Bush and Russian President Vladimir Putin sign the Strategic Offensive Reductions Treaty.
March 25 Hindu Kush earthquakes: A 6.1 magnitude earthquake strikes Nahrin, Afghanistan, killing 800 people and leaving 10,000 homeless. Shenzhou 3 is launched from China.
June 4 The ringed dwarf planet Quaoar is discovered by astronomers Chad Trujillo and Michael Brown at the Palomar Observatory. The Zeyzoun Dam in Zayzun, Syria, fails.
Afghanistan changes its official longform name to the Transitional Islamic State of Afghanistan.
Nadimarg massacre: Islamist militants gather and execute citizens of a Hindu village in Kashmir, killing 24 of the 54 residents.
In the Canal Hotel bombing in Baghdad, 22 people are killed, among them United Nations' Special Representative in Iraq Sérgio Vieira de Mello.
June 30 – Warring parties in the Democratic Republic of the Congo sign a peace accord, bringing an end to the Second Congo War.
February 20 – The Station nightclub fire: A fire broke out at a music venue in West Warwick, Rhode Island, United States, killing 100 people and injuring 230.
August 29 – Imam Ali mosque bombing: A bomb kills at least 125 people, including Mohammad Baqir al-Hakim, at a Shia mosque in Najaf, Iraq.
A subway system in Bangkok opens.

March 7 – The Greek legislative election is held to elect all 300 members of the Hellenic Parliament and the New Democracy party, led by Kostas Karamanlis, won 165 out of 300 seats, ending over 11 years of rule by the PASOK party.
November 7 – The Second Battle of Fallujah starts.
A car bomb of the Jemaah Islamiyah explodes at the Australian embassy in Jakarta, Indonesia, killing 9 people.
January 3 – Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea off the coast of Egypt, killing all 148 aboard, making it one of the deadliest aviation accidents in Egyptian history at the time.
May 13 – Uzbek Interior Ministry and National Security Service troops massacre at least 200 protesters in the city of Andijan.
September 30 – Controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten, sparking outrage and violent riots by Muslims around the world.
Rosa Parks dies of natural causes.

February 14 Former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafic Hariri is assassinated, along with 21 others, by a suicide bomber in Beirut. YouTube, an American online video sharing and social media platform was founded by Steve Chen, Chad Hurley, and Jawed Karim headquartered in San Bruno, California.
December 19 – Chalk's Ocean Airways Flight 101 crashes into the ocean off of Miami Beach in Florida. 20 people are lost.
January 12 – A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 pilgrims.
February 6 – Stephen Harper is sworn in as the Prime Minister of Canada.
June 9 to July 9 – The FIFA World Cup takes place in Germany; Italy defeats France in the final.
March 9 – NASA's Cassini–Huygens spacecraft announces a geyser-like emission of vapor, dust, and small ice crystals on Saturn's moon Enceladus, possibly indicating the presence of water.
British Prime Minister Tony Blair announces his intention to resign by the end of.
March 19 – The first solar eclipse of the year is a partial solar eclipse occurring just 0.7 days before perigee, making it very large. The Moon covers 87.558% of the Sun.

May 10 – As a result of factors including the Blair–Brown deal and falling approval ratings as a result of the Iraq War, British Prime Minister Tony Blair announces his intention to resign as Leader of the Labour Party and Prime Minister, triggering the Labour Party leadership election, in which Chancellor Gordon Brown ran unopposed. Brown would officially replace Blair as Prime Minister on 27 June.
January 4 – Nancy Pelosi becomes the first female speaker of the United States House of Representatives.
Mauritania is the last country to criminalise slavery (officially "abolished" in ), making the practice illegal everywhere in the world.
January 8 – Russian oil supplies to Poland, Germany, and Ukraine are cut as the Russia–Belarus energy dispute escalates; they are restored three days later.
January 21 Stock markets around the world plunge amid growing fears of a U.S. Great Recession, fueled by the subprime mortgage crisis.

March 8 – Barisan Nasional loses two-thirds majority, for the first time since, to opposition during the Malaysian general election but still retains control of government. The coalition also loses majority control of five states to the opposition.
European Certification and Qualification Association is founded.
March 24 – Bhutan holds its first-ever general elections following the adoption of a new Constitution which changed the country from an absolute monarchy to a multiparty democracy.
March 19 – An Energy release of a Gamma-ray burst called the GRB 080319B is the brightest event ever recorded in the Universe.
January 20 – Barack Obama is sworn in as the 44th President of the United States, becoming the first African-American to hold the office.
June 12 – Analog television ends in the United States as part of the digital television transition.
May 19 – German football club RB Leipzig is founded by Red Bull.
October 25 – Two suicide attacks in Baghdad, Iraq, kill 155 people and injure at least 721 people.
June 21 – Greenland gains self-rule.
June 11–July 11 – The FIFA World Cup is held in South Africa, and is won by Spain.
January 19 Mahmoud Al-Mabhouh is assassinated in Dubai. North Caucasian Federal District was split from Southern Federal District by decree of Russian president Dmitry Medvedev.
Qantas Flight 32 suffers an engine failure requiring an emergency landing in Singapore.

November 2 – United States elections were held on Tuesday, November 2,, in the middle of Democratic President Barack Obama's first term. Republicans ended unified Democratic control of Congress and the presidency by winning a majority in the House of Representatives.

March 26 – The ROKS Cheonan, a South Korean Navy ship carrying 104 personnel, sinks off the country's west coast, killing 46. In May, an independent investigation blames North Korea, which denies the allegations.
January 24 – 37 people are killed and more than 180 others are wounded in a bombing at Domodedovo International Airport in Moscow, Russia.
Date selected by the UN as the symbolic date when global population reached seven billion.
May 18 – Porto beats Braga 1–0 in the UEFA Europa League final at the Aviva Stadium.
November 9 – The first nationwide Emergency Alert System test is conducted by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the United States.
December 19 – Liechtenstein becomes the 26th member state of the Schengen Area.

Mohamed Morsi, a member of the Muslim Brotherhood, is elected 5th President of Egypt, the first elected democratically by the Egyptian people, sparking mixed reactions and protests throughout the country.

July 4 CERN announces the discovery of a new particle with properties consistent with the Higgs boson after experiments at the Large Hadron Collider. Sport Club Corinthians Paulista wins the Copa Libertadores by beating the Boca Juniors.
December 6–16 – The FIFA Club World Cup is held in Japan and won by Sport Club Corinthians Paulista.
February 27 – Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh formally transfers power to Vice President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, after a year of mass protests, ending his 33-year-long reign.
June 6 – Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus outbreak first identified.
February 25 – Park Geun-hye becomes the first woman to become the president of South Korea.

The largest tornado ever recorded hits El Reno, United States. This rain-wrapped, multiple-vortex tornado was the widest tornado ever recorded, and results in eight deaths, including four storm-chasers.
October 17 – Microsoft releases Windows 8.1.
December 15 – Fighting between ethnic Dinka and Nuer members of the presidential guard break out in Juba, South Sudan, plunging the country into civil war.
March 24 – Central African Republic President François Bozizé flees to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, after rebel forces capture the nation's capital, Bangui.

November 2 – The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change releases the final part of its Fifth Assessment Report, warning that the world faces "severe, pervasive and irreversible" damage from global emissions of CO2.
The Los Angeles Kings defeat the New York Rangers 3–2 in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Final to win the series 4-1 and win their second Stanley Cup in franchise history.
May 21 – A mass stabbing incident occurred on Taipei Metro's Bannan line from Longshan Temple to Jiangzicui station causing 4 fatalities and 21 injuries.

June 13 International military intervention against ISIL begins. The Los Angeles Kings defeat the New York Rangers 3–2 in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup Final to win the series 4-1 and win their second Stanley Cup in franchise history.
November 12 – The uncrewed Rosetta spacecraft's Philae probe successfully lands on Comet 67P, the first time in history that a spacecraft has landed on such an object.
March 6 – NASA's Dawn probe enters orbit around Ceres, becoming the first spacecraft to visit a dwarf planet.
August 17 – A bombing takes place inside the Erawan Shrine at the Ratchaprasong intersection in Pathum Wan District, Bangkok, Thailand, killing 20 people and injuring 125.
January 1 – Lithuania officially adopts the euro as its currency, replacing the litas, and becomes the 19th Eurozone country.
October 10 – A series of suicide bombings kills at least 100 people at a peace rally in Ankara, Turkey, and injures more than 400 others.
"Exclusive: Investigators '90 percent sure' bomb downed Russian plane". Reuters.
October 13 – The Maldives announces its decision to withdraw from the Commonwealth of Nations.

April 8 – Pope Francis' apostolic exhortation Amoris laetitia (dated March 19) is published in the Vatican; it appears to amend the Roman Catholic Church's position on the availability of sacraments to Catholics who have divorced and contracted a civil remarriage.
The International Atomic Energy Agency announces that Iran has adequately dismantled its nuclear weapons program, allowing the United Nations to lift sanctions immediately.
November 6 – The government of India announces the demonetisation of certain banknotes, causing prolonged cash shortages in the weeks that follow and significant disruption throughout the economy.
February 7 – North Korea launches a reconnaissance satellite named Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4 into space, it is condemned internationally as a long-range ballistic missile test.

January 21 – Gambian constitutional crisis: Following the military intervention of ECOWAS, President Yahya Jammeh resigns from office after 23 years in power and flees into exile to Equatorial Guinea; the democratically elected Adama Barrow assumes office as President of The Gambia. Millions of people worldwide join the Women's March following the inauguration of Donald Trump as President of the United States. 420 marches were reported in the U.S. and 168 in other countries, becoming the largest single-day protest in American history.

Sutherland Springs church shooting: A gunman opens fire in a Baptist church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, United States, killing 26 people and injuring 20 more. It was the deadliest shooting in an American place of worship in modern history, surpassing the Charleston church shooting of and the Waddell Buddhist temple shooting of.
January 29 – A gunman opens fire at a mosque in Quebec City, Canada, killing 6 and injuring 19 others.
June 26 – The America's Cup yacht race, sailed in Bermuda, is won by New Zealand's Aotearoa.

August 25–30 – Hurricane Harvey strikes the United States as a Category 4 hurricane, causing catastrophic damage to the Houston metropolitan area, mostly due to record-breaking floods. At least 108 deaths are recorded, and total damage reaches $125 billion, making Harvey the costliest natural disaster in United States history, tied with Hurricane Katrina in.
October 23 – The Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge, the world's longest sea crossing bridge, is opened by Chinese Paramount leader Xi Jinping.

September 6 – The Supreme Court of India decriminalises homosexuality.; Brazilian congressman Jair Bolsonaro is stabbed in the stomach at Juiz de Fora, Minas Gerais, during a rally while running for the presidency.
Eleven people are killed during the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting.
March 24 – In over 900 cities internationally, people participate in demonstrations against gun violence and mass shootings, calling for stronger gun control in the "March for Our Lives".
September 22 – An attack at a military parade kills 30 people (including 5 attackers) and injures 70 more in Ahvaz, Iran.

August 8 – Nyonoksa radiation accident: Reports indicate that there may have been a nuclear explosion at the Nyonoksa weapons-testing site in Arkhangelsk Oblast, Russia. At least five people were killed and three others injured in the blast, with radiation levels in Severodvinsk, 47 km (29 mi) from the site, being 20 times above normal levels temporarily.
A mass shooting occurs at Saugus High School in Santa Clarita, California, United States, resulting in 3 deaths (including the perpetrator) and 3 injuries.

September 21 – U.S. President Donald Trump approves deployment of several hundred troops and military equipment to Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates following the September 14 attack on Saudi oil refineries.
Venezuelan presidential crisis: Venezuelan opposition leader and disputed interim President Juan Guaidó leads an attempted uprising against President Nicolás Maduro.
January 3 – Chinese probe Chang'e 4 becomes the first artificial object to land on the far side of the Moon.
October 26 – NASA confirms the existence of molecular water on the sunlit side of the Moon, near Clavius crater, at concentrations of up to 412 parts per million.

Western Sahara conflict, Arab–Israeli conflict: Israel and Morocco normalise diplomatic relations. Simultaneously, the United States reaffirms its previous recognition of Moroccan sovereignty over the Western Sahara and announces plans to build a consulate there.
COVID-19 pandemic: The global death toll from COVID-19 exceeds 200,000. The UK becomes the fifth country to report 20,000 deaths.
Hurricane Sally makes landfall on the Alabama coast as a high-end Category 2 hurricane, causing over $8 billion in damages and killing 8 people.
June 24 – The Mongolian legislative election is held to elect the State Great Khural and the ruling Mongolian People's Party wins 62 out of 76 seats.
January 13 – In Lyon, France, the first transplant of both arms and shoulders is performed on an Icelandic patient at the Édouard Herriot Hospital.
The second round of the Chilean presidential election is held; leftist candidate Gabriel Boric is elected President.Artistic conception of the James Webb Space Telescope.
July 23–August 8 – The Summer Olympics were held in Tokyo, Japan. They were originally scheduled for 24 July–9 August, but were postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
November 30 – Barbados becomes a republic on its 55th anniversary of independence while remaining a member of the Commonwealth of Nations.

Roscosmos launches the Soyuz MS-19 mission, which carries an Expedition 66 crewmember and two Channel One Russia personnel to the International Space Station. The two Channel One crew will perform principal photography on the film Vyzov aboard the station.
February 3 – Islamic State leader Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi is killed in Atme during a counter-terrorism raid by U.S. special forces in north-western Syria.

January 1 France takes over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union, after the Slovenian presidency. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership, the largest free trade area in the world, comes into effect for Australia, Brunei, Cambodia, China, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change releases the second part of its Sixth Assessment Report on climate change. It concludes that many impacts are on the verge of becoming "irreversible".

February 26 – Russian invasion of Ukraine: The EU, US, and their allies commit to removing Russian banks from the SWIFT payment system, as well as imposing measures on the Russian Central Bank and further restrictions on Russian elites. These and other sanctions fuel a financial crisis in Russia.

Russian financial crisis: In an unprecedented move, Switzerland, Monaco, Singapore and South Korea impose unilateral sanctions over Russia including the introduction of export controls and asset freezes.

August 23 India's Chandrayaan-3 becomes the first spacecraft to land near the south pole of the Moon, carrying a lunar lander named Vikram and a lunar rover named Pragyan. Wagner Group leader Yevgeny Prigozhin, founder Dmitry Utkin and eight others are killed when their plane crashes in Russia.

November 30 – Brazil announces it will join OPEC+ at a meeting of the organization to discuss oil output strategy in. Brazil is the largest oil producer in South America, producing 4.6 million barrels per day of oil and gas.
The deadliest mass shooting in the Czech Republic's history occurs at a Prague university, with 15 killed, including the perpetrator, and 25 others wounded.
Israel and Hamas agree to a four-day ceasefire, the first pause in fighting since 7 October, during which many Israeli hostages will be released, in exchange for Palestinian prisoners.
July 19 – Typhoon Doksuri forms in the eastern Pacific Ocean, going on to kill 137 people in Southeast Asia.
September 30 – The UK becomes the first G7 country to phase out coal power for electric generation, after 142 years of using the energy source.
September 15 – Ryan Wesley Routh is accused of attempting to assassinate Donald Trump in Florida. Routh is later captured and arrested, and a trial date has been set for.
A major landslide in Papua New Guinea kills 160–2,000+ people, with many more buried.
Spanish floods: Spain experiences its worst flooding in half a century, with over 200 killed and many more missing, as a year's worth of rain falls in eight hours.
October 12 – The long-period comet C/ A3 (Tsuchinshan–ATLAS), described as the "comet of the century", makes its closest approach to Earth.
Central African general election: Incumbent president Faustin-Archange Touadéra wins reelection for a third term.
Operation Spiderweb: Ukraine launches a large drone attack on Russian military bases. More than 40 aircraft of the Russian Air Force are attacked.
November 3 – A powerful Mw 6.3 earthquake shakes the provinces of Balkh and Samangan in Afghanistan, causing 31 deaths and 956 injuries.

May 6 – German federal election: Friedrich Merz is elected Chancellor of Germany in the second round of parliamentary voting, hours after being defeated in the first round, a first in post-WWII German history.
Malawian general election: Peter Mutharika is elected president for a second non-consecutive term.
May 31 – The Colombian presidential election is scheduled to be held.
January 22 – The United States will officially leave the World Health Organization.
The United States launches several airstrikes on multiple locations across northern Venezuela, capturing Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro and first lady Cilia Flores.
The Brazilian general election is scheduled to be held.
August 30 – The Estonian presidential election is scheduled to be held.
– – The Third Dynasty of Ur. The Ziggurat of Ur is built.
–1800 – The Sintashta culture emerges in the northern Eurasian Steppe.
– : Epic poetry is written in the Sumerian language, including the Epic of Gilgamesh. In Chalcolithic Europe, the two circles of bluestones that form the inner part of Stonehenge are erected.
In Chalcolithic Europe, the two circles of bluestones that form the inner part of Stonehenge are erected.
– Yu the Great establishes the Xia dynasty in China.
: Ancient migrants from India reach Australia and mix with Indigenous Australians.
: Akkadian Empire falls under attack by the Guti, a mountain people from the northeast.
– (middle chronology): Utu-hengal, first king of the third dynasty of Ur, also called the Neo-Sumerian Empire.
: Beginning of Middle Minoan period in Crete.
–2030 : The Epic of Gilgamesh is written in Mesopotamia in Akkadian.
: A Guti army swept down from the Zagros Mountains and defeated the demoralized Akkadian army. They took Agade, the capital of Akkad, and destroyed it thoroughly.
: Mount Edgecumbe volcano erupts near present-day Sitka, Alaska.
: Canal Bahr Yusuf (current name) is created when the waterway from the Nile to the natural lake (now Lake Moeris) is widened and deepened to create a canal.
– : "Head of a man from Nineveh" (modern Kuyunjik, Iraq) is made. It is now in Iraq Museum, Baghdad.
: Earliest evidence of maize cultivation in Central America.
: Lugal-Zage-Si of Umma conquers Gu-Edin and unites Sumer as a single kingdom.
2900 – : Mesopotamian wars of the Early Dynastic period continue.
–There is archaeological evidence that the site of Assur was occupied at around this time.
: End of Fifth Dynasty. Pharaoh Unas died.
: Dangun establishes Gojoseon, the first Korean kingdom, according to Korean mythology.
: Scribal schools flourish throughout Sumer.
: People in what is now Peru rely on fish and mussels for food.

: By this time, kings in Sumer have ceased to be automatically high priests of the city deity. (Roux 1980) Infiltration and conquest of Mesopotamia by ancient Semitic-speaking peoples begins. (1968 RD Almanac).
: Cylinder seal from Sumer and its impression are made. It is now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
: Kish is lost to Hamazi tribesmen of the Kurdistan mountains; Elam under the Awan dynasty occupies parts of Sumer. (Roux 1980).

: Mesannepada, who has already dominated the city of Nippur, takes advantage of an eclipse of power in Kish (caused by an incursion by the Elamites of Awan) to seize the city. He becomes the ruler of all of Lower Mesopotamia as he becomes the king of Kish, and his name appears on a pearl in Mari.
: Reign of Mesilim, king of Kish. He was an apparent suzerain over the Lagash king Luga-shag-engur and the Adab king Nin-kisalsi.
–2493 : Reign of Khafre. the Pyramid of Khafre is built, along with the Great Sphinx of Giza, a monumental sculpture of a pharaoh (either Khafre or Khufu) with a lion's body.
–2485 : Reign of A'annepada, king of Ur.
– : Reign of Khufu, second pharaoh of the Fourth Dynasty. The height of the Old Kingdom under the reigns of Khufu, Khafre and Menkaure.
Imhotep, vizier and architect of Djoser, constructs the Pyramid of Djoser, Egypt's earliest stone edifice, in Saqqara.
End of the Early Dynastic I Period, and the beginning of the Early Dynastic II Period in Mesopotamia.
Abandonment of the Mature Harappan settlement at Kalibangan in India due to the drying-up of the Ghaggar River.
–2494 : Fourth Dynasty of Egypt. c. – : The reign of the pharaoh Sneferu and his vizier Nefermaat.
: Supposed beginning of the mythical reign of the legendary Yellow Emperor of China.
: Estimated ending of the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture in the region of modern-day Romania, Moldova, and southwestern Ukraine.
– 2650 : Second Dynasty wars in Ancient Egypt.
– : Seated Harp Player, from Keros, Cyclades, is made. It is now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
– Akkadian language names are recorded from about this time period.

: Suggested date for an asteroid or comet impact occurring between Africa and Antarctica, around the time of a lunar eclipse on May 10, based on an analysis of flood stories. Possibly causing the Burckle crater and Fenambosy Chevron.
– 2334 : Mesopotamian wars of the Early Dynastic period.
: The 365-day calendar year was installed in ancient Egypt, with fixed lunar months of 30 days + 5 epagomenal days.
– 2600 : Votive statues from the Square Temple of Eshnunna (modern Tell Ashmar, Iraq) were made. One of them is now in the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago.

Before : An image of a deity (detail from a cong) recovered from Tomb 12 in Fanshan, Yuyao, Zhejiang, is made during the Neolithic period by the Liangzhu culture. It is now kept at Zhejiang Provincial Museum, Hangzhou.
: Jawa, Jordan is founded along with the world's first known dam.
: Death of Egyptian First Dynasty pharaoh Semerkhet, whose name marks the first definitive use of a Nebty name.
: Early agriculture in North Africa.
: Camels are domesticated in Egypt.
: Oldest adobe building in the Americas was built in what is now Peru.
?: Predynastic period ends in Ancient Egypt.
?: First stage in the construction of Stonehenge.
?: The first temple of Tarxien is in use by the Neolithic inhabitants of Malta.
?: Early Dynastic period starts in Ancient Egypt.
?: Neolithic people in Ireland build the 250,000-ton (230,000-tonne) Newgrange solar-oriented passage tomb.

: Ljubljana Marshes Wheel is a wooden wheel that was found in the Ljubljana Marsh in Slovenia. Radiocarbon dating showed that it is approximately 5,150 years old, which makes it the oldest wooden wheel yet discovered.
?: Beginning of the reign of Narmer, first pharaoh to unify Ancient Egypt and founder of the 1st Dynasty.
: The earliest phase of Stonehenge construction begins.
?: Sumerian cuneiform writing system.
: to 3000 : Face of a woman, from Uruk (modern Warka, Iraq) is made; it is now in the Iraq Museum, Baghdad (stolen and recovered in 2003).
: Harappan script is developed in Indus Valley.
: Archaeological evidence suggests the transition from Copper to Bronze took place around.
Ancient Egypt begins using clay, bone and ivory tags to label boxes, possibly an example of proto-writing.

-3000 : Evidence of proto-Thracians or proto-Dacians in the prehistoric period; Proto-Dacian or proto-Thracian people developed from a mixture of indigenous peoples and Indo-Europeans from the time of Proto-Indo-European expansion in the Early Bronze Age.
: The Eruption of Mount Isarog in the Philippines.
: The first monument of which there is still a trace (Duma na nGiall) is built on the Hill of Tara, the ancient seat of the High King of Ireland.
: First known zoo at Hierakonpolis.
: The Sumerians develop a logographic script, cuneiform.
: The oldest estimated germination of Alerce Milenario with more conservative dates of only ‘c.1653 ’.
: First known zoo at Hierakonpolis.
: Sumerian temple record keepers redesign the stamp seal in the form of a cylinder.
: The oldest estimated germination of Alerce Milenario with more conservative dates of only ‘c.1653 ’.
: The Sumerians develop a logographic script, cuneiform.
: Pictographic proto-writing starts developing towards writing proper in Sumer, thus starting what is technically considered history.
Civilization in Sumer (Uruk period).
Mnajdra solar temple complex, Malta.
Maize is domesticated at Balsas River by the Tehuacán culture.
Fortified town at Amri on the west bank of the Indus River.
In Egypt, evidence found of mummification around this time at a cemetery in Nekhen.
Settlement of the River area of Barbuda (c. ), formation of sand dunes on Palmetto Point.
In the south of England, a rapid expansion of monument building occurred around.
Indus Valley civilisation in South Asia.
In the city of Uruk, southern Mesopotamia, groups of tokens representing commercial transactions begin to be enclosed in hollow clay balls and kept in archives.
The Maykop culture, a major Bronze Age archaeological culture in the Western Caucasus region of Southern Russia, began around.
An earthquake near a Neolithic culture at Sotira in Cyprus destroys much of the local infrastructure.
In Syria, mass graves at Tell Brak, dating from c. to 3600, have been unearthed, suggesting advanced warfare around this period.
Ubaid period came to an abrupt end in eastern Arabia and the Oman peninsula at.

– the first year of the Hebrew calendar.
, more than 100 dwellings surrounding a community center, a cemetery and a kiln are built in Jiangzhai, near modern Xi'an, China.
Metallurgy during the Copper Age in Europe.
Megalithic monuments are constructed in Brittany, Portugal, central and southern France, Corsica and Great Britain.
Approximate time of the construction of the Merheleva Ridge complex.
Susa is a center of pottery production; c. potter's wheel in Mesopotamia.
Susa is a center of pottery production; c. potter's wheel in Mesopotamia.
Clay pots and vats discovered at a sprawling cave system in southern Armenia near the border with Iran shows signs of an organized effort to press and distill grapes.
